bestBHT.bht: Under the guidance of the Holy Spirit, Zacharias prophesied about the Messiah and his own son John. Filled with the Spirit, he grasped the highest meaning of the Messianic message. This hymn, known as the Benedictus, reflects Zacharias' pious faith and the immediate influence of the Holy Spirit. His ability to speak again was a remarkable instance of God's goodness, as his tongue became the organ of divine inspiration. Through the Spirit's movement, Zacharias uttered prophetic words about the coming of the Messiah and the role his son would play.

Albert Barnes: Filled with the Holy Ghost - See Luke 1:15.
This song of Zechariah partakes of all. It is principally employed in the praises of God, but it also predicts the future character and preaching of John.
John Calvin: We have lately explained this phrase to mean, that the servants of God received more abundantly the grace of the Spirit, of which, at other times, they were not destitute.

This implies that divine inspiration, at that time, rested upon him in an extraordinary measure, in consequence of which he did not speak like a man or private person, but all that he uttered was heavenly instruction.

This was a remarkable instance of the goodness of God, that not only did Zacharias recover the power of speech, which he had not enjoyed for nine months, but his tongue became the organ of the Holy Spirit.
Philip Schaff: The BENEDICTUS presents, therefore, not only the faith of a pious Jewish priest, not only the result of the long months of silent reflection to which Zacharias had been subjected, but also these as guided, moved, and uttered under the immediate influence of the Holy Spirit.

Without inspiration the pious priest would doubtless have adopted the same tone, the same Old Testament phraseology, but his words could not have been prophetic of the coming of the Messiah nor of the part to be taken by his own son.

The hymn may be divided into five stanzas (of three lines each, though some make more). As is natural, the song of Zacharias is more national in its character, the song of Mary more individual. The Benedictus is more priestly, the Magnificat more royal.
Archibald T. Robertson: Prophesied (επροφητευσεν). Under the guidance of the Holy Spirit.
This Benedictus (Ευλογητος, Blessed) of Zacharias (Luke 1:68-79) may be what is referred to in verse Luke 1:64 'he began to speak blessing God' (ευλογων).
He, like Mary, was full of the Holy Spirit and had caught the Messianic message in its highest meaning.
John Gill: And his father Zacharias was filled with the Holy Ghost,.... With a spirit of prophecy..."
and prophesied saying; the following things, relating to the Messiah, his incarnation and redemption by him...
Whence it appears, that the following song is of divine inspiration; and that Zacharias spake it as he was moved by the Holy Ghost, as the prophets of old did.
John Wesley: And Zacharias prophesied — Of things immediately to follow. But it is observable, he speaks of Christ chiefly; of John only, as it were, incidentally.

bhtAttempts.bht: Under the guidance of the Holy Spirit, Zacharias prophesied, joining Mary in being filled with the Spirit and understanding the Messianic message. This Benedictus of Zacharias praises God and predicts the future character and preaching of John, all inspired by the Holy Spirit. His hymn, more priestly in character, can be divided into five stanzas. It is a remarkable instance of God's goodness that Zacharias not only regained his ability to speak, but that his tongue became the organ of the Holy Spirit, allowing him to prophesy about the Messiah and his son.

Under the guidance of the Holy Spirit, Zacharias prophesied, joining Mary in being filled with the Spirit and understanding the Messianic message. This Benedictus of Zacharias praises God and predicts the future character and preaching of John, all inspired by the Holy Spirit. His hymn, more priestly in character, can be divided into five stanzas. It is a remarkable instance of God's goodness that Zacharias not only regained his ability to speak, but that his tongue became the organ of the Holy Spirit.

Guided by the Holy Spirit, Zacharias prophesied and praised God. Like Mary, he was filled with the Spirit and understood the Messianic message. His hymn, called the Benedictus, predicts the future character and preaching of his son John. This song reflects Zacharias' pious faith as well as the immediate influence of the Holy Spirit. Through divine inspiration, Zacharias spoke prophetic words about the coming Messiah. His ability to speak again after months of silence was a testament to God's goodness and the extraordinary measure of the Spirit's presence upon him.

Under the guidance of the Holy Spirit, Zacharias prophesied about the Messiah and his own son John. Filled with the Spirit, he grasped the highest meaning of the Messianic message. This hymn, known as the Benedictus, reflects Zacharias' pious faith and the immediate influence of the Holy Spirit. His ability to speak again was a remarkable instance of God's goodness, as his tongue became the organ of divine inspiration. Through the Spirit's movement, Zacharias uttered prophetic words about the coming of the Messiah and the role his son would play.

Guided by the Holy Spirit, Zacharias prophesied and joined Mary in understanding the Messianic message. His hymn, the Benedictus, praises God and predicts the character and preaching of his son John. Zacharias, filled with the Spirit, spoke under divine inspiration, his words prophetic of the Messiah's coming. The restoration of his speech was a testament to God's goodness and the extraordinary measure of the Spirit's presence upon him. Through the organ of the Holy Spirit, Zacharias proclaimed the redemption brought by the incarnate Christ.
